title: Charles Eyre (cricketer)
text:
Charles Howard Eyre (26 March 1883 – 25 September 1915) was an <a href="English%20people">English</a> first-class <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er, educator and <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> officer.
The son of <a href="John%20Eyre%20%28Archdeacon%20of%20Sheffield%29">John Eyre</a>, the <a href="Archdeacon%20of%20Sheffield%20and%20Rotherham">Archdeacon of Sheffield</a>, he was born in <a href="Toxteth">Toxteth</a>, <a href="Liverpool">Liverpool</a> in March 1883. He was educated at <a href="Harrow%20School">Harrow School</a>, where he was a multi-talented sportsman who played cricket, <a href="association%20football">football</a>, <a href="Eton%20Fives">Eton Fives</a> and <a href="Rackets%20%28sport%29">rackets</a>. He was also head of school in 1901. From Harrow, he went up as a scholar to <a href="Pembroke%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Pembroke College, Cambridge</a>. While studying at Cambridge, he played <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> for <a href="Cambridge%20University%20Cricket%20Club">Cambridge University</a> from 1903 to 1906, making 29 appearances. He scored 1,092 runs for Cambridge, <a href="batting%20average%20%28cricket%29">averaging</a> 21.84 with one century and four half centuries. His century, a score of 153, came against <a href="Yorkshire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Yorkshire</a> in 1906. He was a good fielder, taking 40 catches in first-class cricket. He played for the <a href="Marylebone%20Cricket%20Club">Marylebone Cricket Club</a> in 1905 during their tour of North America, with Eyre making a single first-class appearance on the tour against the <a href="Philadelphian%20cricket%20team">Gentlemen of Philadelphia</a> at <a href="Germantown%20Cricket%20Club">Germantown</a>.
After graduating from Cambridge, Eyre returned to Harrow to become an assistant master and also served as honorary secretary of the Harrow Association. Shortly after the outbreak of the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a> in July 1914, he was commissioned into the <a href="King%27s%20Royal%20Rifle%20Corps">King's Royal Rifle Corps</a> as a <a href="Second%20lieutenant%23United%20Kingdom%20%26amp%3B%20other%20Commonwealth%20countries">second lieutenant</a>. By July 1915, he held the rank of <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a> and had been made a temporary <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a>. Eyre was killed in action on 25 September 1915, on the first day of the <a href="Battle%20of%20Loos">Battle of Loos</a>.
